title: Student, 20, who ran a county lines drug network from university halls jailed for 30 months
text:
Seif Hashim, 20, (pictured) was yesterday jailed for 30 months

A student who ran a county lines drug operation from his hall of residence was yesterday jailed for 30 months.

Seif Hashim, 20, enrolled in a physiotherapy course as cover while he was selling large quantities of cocaine, heroin and cannabis.

Police raided his Kent University room and found drugs, scales and bags ready for distribution to hundreds of customers in a 'significant' dealing operation.

The Old Bailey heard Hashim used his course in Gillingham, Kent, to hide his activities.

Alexandra Felix, prosecuting, said: 'Whereas he may have been on a course, this was definitely somebody in the drug dealing business.'

Hashim admitted three drug charges related to county lines which describes the phones used to set up deals from cities to smaller towns.

Hashim enrolled in a physiotherapy course at Kent University (pictured) as cover while he was selling large quantities of cocaine, heroin and cannabis

He admitted three drug charges related to county lines which describes the phones used to set up deals from cities to smaller towns (file image)

The landmark case, thought to be the first of its kind, comes just a month after a drug gangs expert warned county lines dealers are increasingly becoming university students.

Dr Mohammed Qasim, of Leeds Beckett University, said they use the 'student image' for an alibi if they are searched by police.
